citation.article-title: Tindallia magadii gen. nov., sp. nov.: an alkaliphilic anaerobic ammonifier from soda lake deposits.

p.s: Description of Tindallia magadii sp. nov.
Tindallia magadii Ma.ga.di.i. Named after its habitat—soda-depositing Lake Magadi located in Central Africa)
Rods single, in pairs, and in chains, 0.5–0.6 μm in diameter, and 1.2–2.5 μm in length.
Cell wall structure of Gram-positive type.
Non-motile.
Multiplication occurs by fission.
No sporulation was observed and the culture is not viable after heating at 70°C.
Obligately anaerobic, oxygen sensitive.
Sulfide is needed only as a reductant.
Mesophilic, minimum temperature for growth 19°C, optimum at 37°C, maximum at 47°C.
True alkaliphile, with minimum pH for growth of 7.5; optimum at pH 8.5; maximum at pH 10.5.
Sodium dependent with optimum concentration for growth of 0.5–1.0 M.
No growth in the absence of sodium.
Fermentative.
Non-hydrolytic.
Catabolic substrates are limited.
Ferments amino acids and a few compounds of central metabolism as pyruvate, citrate.

Utilizes arginine and compounds of the ornithine cycle as preferred substrates with production of ammonium, which is stimulatory at low concentrations but is inhibitory at concentrations over 9 mM and at high pH.
Carbon products of fermentation are mainly acetate.
Minor components are formate, propionate, and iso-valerate, depending on the substrate.
Non-carbon products are hydrogen and ammonium from nitrogenous substrates.
Reduces DMSO to DMS and Fe(III) to Fe(II).
For anabolic needs, utilizes amino acids, does not require vitamins, reduced sulfur compounds or ammonium (when nitrogenous compounds are fermented).
G+C content of the genomic DNA is 37.6 mol% (optical reassociation).
Phylogenetic position is within the branch of low G+C clostridia.
Habitat: soda depositing lake, type strain isolated from Lake Magadi.
Type strain: Z-7934T (= DSM 10318).
